questions.question:
Question 1: Ischemia occurs in the brain when the cerebral blood flow falls below  
.
questions.explanation:
A decrease in the cerebral blood flow below 20 mL/100 g/min causes reversible ischemia. If this state is prolonged for several hours to days, it can lead to infarction. A decrease in CBF to 0 
causes the death of the brain tissue within 4–10 min. Normal cerebral blood flow (CBF) in an adult brain at rest is 50–55 mL/100 g/min.

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient presented with acute onset of weakness of the left arm which resolved completely in 
10 days. He is known to have mitral stenosis, hypertension and dyslipidemia. What is the 
most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This patient with mitral stenosis and acute onset weakness of the left arm is most likely to have 
had an embolic stroke, which is a type of ischemic stroke. Embolic strokes tend to occur suddenly 
with maximum neurologic deficit present at onset. Mitral stenosis is known to cause atrial fibrillation and is a common cause of cardioembolic 
stroke. Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset 
(stroke-like symptoms) lasting for less than 24 hours. This occurs due to focal ischemia of the 
brain, retina or cochlea. Most TIAs last for less than 1 hour to a few minutes. There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months 
following a TIA.

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient presented with right-sided hemiparesis that completely resolved in 4-6 hours. What 
score will you use to determine the risk of a future stroke in this patient?
questions.explanation:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a transient ischemic attack. The risk of stroke 
following TIAs is determined by the ABCD2 score. CHADS2-VASc score is used to determine the risk of stroke in a patient with atrial fibrillation. CURB-65 is a scoring system used to predict mortality in patients with community-acquired 
pneumonia. 1096 
Sold by @itachibot APACHE II is a scoring system used to predict ICU mortality.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 67-year-old patient with hypertension, diabetes, and asthma is found to have an irregularly 
irregular pulse during a routine physical examination. ECG findings are shown below. How is 1087 
Sold by @itachibot the risk of stroke determined in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario along with the ECG findings are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. The risk of 
stroke in this condition is determined by CHA2DS2-VASC score. The ECG show irregular QRS complexes of normal morphology and absent P waves.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 73-year-old woman who was brought to the ER with hemiparesis was found to have a 
lacunar infarction. What causes this condition?
questions.explanation:
Lacunar infarcts, also called small vessel stroke, refer to infarction following atherothrombotic or 
lipohyalinotic occlusion of small penetrating arteries in the brain. These penetrating arteries 
arise from the stem of the middle cerebral artery, circle of Willis, and basilar and vertebral 
arteries. The principal risk factors are hypertension and old age. The image below shows two lacunar infarctions on a CT.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is not caused by a lacunar stroke?
questions.explanation:
Crural monoplegia with urinary incontinence is not caused by a lacunar stroke. It is caused by 
the occlusion of A2 segment of the anterior cerebral artery. Crural monoplegia refers to a 
monoplegia of the lower limbs. The types of lacunar syndromes are as follows: • Pure motor hemiparesis - infarct in the posterior limb of the internal capsule 1097 
Sold by @itachibot • Pure sensory stroke - infarct in the thalamus • Ataxic hemiparesis - infarct in the pons or internal capsule • Dysarthria and clumsy hand syndrome - infarction in the pons or internal capsule. The ACA is divided into two segments: • The pre-communal (A1) circle of Willis, or stem, which connects the internal carotid artery to the 
anterior communicating artery • The post-communal (A2) segment distal to the anterior communicating artery

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient is diagnosed with an ischaemic stroke. His son says that he holds the comb 
incorrectly while combing his hair. During the evaluation, he was unable to button his shirt 
when requested. The lesion is most likely to be in which lobe?
questions.explanation:
1098 
Sold by @itachibot The given scenario where the patient is unable to perform learned skilled movements is suggestive 
of apraxia. The lesion is likely to be in the dominant parietal lobe as apraxia is a feature of a lesion 
in this area. The features of dominant parietal lobe lesions are as follows: • Apraxia - inability to perform learned skilled movements • Acalculia - difficulty performing simple mathematical tasks • Alexia - inability to recognize or read written words or letters • Agnosia - inability to recognize and identify objects, persons, or sounds • Dysphasia - language disorder marked by deficiency in the generation of speech and its 
comprehension • Contralateral inferior homonymous quadrantanopia • Gerstmann syndrome (acalculia, dysgraphia, finger agnosia, right-left confusion) Features of non-dominant parietal lobe lesions include: • Spatial disorientation • Constructional apraxia • Contralateral inferior homonymous quadrantanopia • Contralateral hemineglect.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following features is not likely to be seen in a patient with a temporal lobe 
lesion?
questions.explanation:
Neglect is not a feature of temporal lobe lesion. It is a feature of a non-dominant parietal lobe 
lesion. Features of dominant temporal lobe lesions: • Complex hallucinations - visual, auditory or olfactory • Memory impairment • Complex partial seizures • Wernicke’s aphasia • Contralateral superior quadrantanopia Features of non-dominant temporal lobe lesions: • Poor non-verbal memory • Loss of musical skills • Complex hallucinations • Contralateral superior quadrantanopia. 1099 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A 43-year-old man is brought to the hospital due to extremely aggressive behaviour towards 
his family. His family members also say that he has become forgetful and has developed 
urinary incontinence. Which of the following lobes is likely to be involved in his disease 
process?
questions.explanation:
Antisocial behavior, urinary incontinence, and impaired memory in this patient are suggestive of 
frontal lobe involvement. Features of frontal lobe lesions: • Disinhibition • Lack of initiative • Antisocial behavior • Impaired memory • Incontinence • Grasp reflexes • Anosmia.

questions.question:
Question 10: In the sagittal section of the brain given below if the coloured area is affected, which of the 
following is not seen? 1089 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Paracentral lobule (PCL) is the continuation of the precentral and postcentral gyri of the 
superolateral surface into the medial surface of cerebral hemisphere. It controls the motor and 
sensory innervations of the contralateral lower extremity. It is also responsible for cortical control 
of micturition and defecation. The anterior two-thirds of PCL belong to Brodmann area 4, it reflects the primary motor cortex 
for the muscles of contralateral leg, foot, and perineum,it is functionally important in control of 
bladder and anal sphincters. Therefore, it's called the cortical center of defecation and micturition. The posterior third of the PCL contains 3,2 and 1, it reflects the primary somatosensory 
representation of the leg and foot. The A2 segment of the anterior cerebral artery supplies the paracentral lobule. Lesions in the 
paracentral lobule lead to: • Weakness and loss of sensation in contralateral lower limb • Urinary incontinence • Fecal incontinence.

questions.question:
Question 11: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal 
gyrus?
questions.explanation:
Lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus cause Wernicke’s or Fluent aphasia 
due to the involvement of the Wernicke's area. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that 
make little sense (area no 22). Broca's (Option B) or motor/non-fluent aphasia is seen in lesions of the inferior frontal gyrus 
which contains the motor speech area. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of 
functional words. 1100 
Sold by @itachibot Comprehension of written language and the ability to name objects are compromised in anomic 
aphasia (Option C). This aphasia is caused by damage to the angular gyrus that disrupts visual 
information processing and transmission to the Wernicke area. Conduction aphasia (Option D) is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve 
fibers connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and 
paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 60-year-old patient with atrial fibrillation complains of sudden onset weakness of the right 
lower limb, with urinary and faecal incontinence. MRI shows an ischaemic stroke involving 
the left anterior cerebral artery. Which of the following features would you not expect to see 
in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Prosopagnosia, also called face blindness, is the inability to recognize faces including one's own 
image. This occurs due to occipitotemporal lobe damage, seen in posterior cerebral artery (PCA) 
strokes involving cortical branch occlusion. It is not seen in anterior cerebral artery strokes. The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies parts of the frontal lobe, corpus callosum, paracentral 
lobule, and other deeper structures. Signs and symptoms of ACA occlusion and structures involved: • Urinary incontinence, fecal incontinence • Paratonic rigidity • Abulia (Akinetic mutism), lack of spontaneity, slowness • Gait impairment • Paralysis of contralateral foot and leg • Paresis of the contralateral arm • Cortical sensory loss over the contralateral lower limb • Dyspraxia of left limbs, tactile aphasia in left limbs.

questions.question:
Question 13: Infarction of area of distribution of which of the following arteries is most likely to be seen in 
a patient with hemiplegia?
questions.explanation:
Hemiplegia is most commonly associated with infarction of the area of distribution of middle 
cerebral artery. Middle cerebral artery supplies the motor cortex responsible for sending the output to the motor 
neurons. Infarction in this territory leads to hemiplegia. Infarction of area of distribution of vertebral, anterior spinal and posterior cerebral arteries can 
also lead to hemiplegia. 1101 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following features is not expected to be seen in a patient with a right middle 
cerebral artery infarct?
questions.explanation:
Aphasia is not a feature of right middle cerebral artery infarct (MCA). Aphasia occurs when there is damage to the dominant hemisphere, i.e., left hemisphere. The 
dominant hemisphere contains the language network which includes Broca’s area, Wernicke’s 
area, their interconnections and connections with frontal, parietal and temporal areas. The MCA originates from the internal carotid artery. The stem of the MCA is referred to as the M1 
segment. It gives rise to cortical and penetrating/lenticulostriate branches. MCA stem occlusion leads to : • Contralateral hemiplegia • Hemianesthesia 1102 
Sold by @itachibot • Homonymous hemianopia • Global aphasia (dominant hemisphere) • Anosognosia, constructional apraxia, neglect (non-dominant hemisphere) Occlusion of the lenticulostriate branches of MCA (lacunar stroke) may affect the genu of the 
internal capsule. This can lead to dysarthria with contralateral clumsy hand (fine motor 
weakness).

questions.question:
Question 15: Visual field examination of a 52-year-old stroke patient reveals the finding shown in the 
image. During examination, you notice that he is not able to comprehend your instructions 
and sometimes gives irrelevant replies. What is the likely site of arterial occlusion? 1091 
Sold by @itachibot

options.c: Left M2 segment of MCA – inferior division
options.d: Right M2 segment of MCA – superior division

questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of homonymous right superior quadrantanopia (pie in the sky 
appearance) and sensory aphasia. These are seen in occlusion of the inferior division of the 
opposite side middle cerebral artery (MCA). Parts of the middle cerebral artery: • The MCA originates from the internal carotid artery. The stem of the MCA is referred to as the 
M1 segment. • In the Sylvian fissure, the MCA divides into superior and inferior divisions. These branches are 
referred to as the M2 segments of the MCA. Occlusion of the following sites and their effects are given below: • MCA stem (M1) - leads to contralateral hemiplegia, hemianesthesia and homonymous 
hemianopia amongst other features • Superior division of MCA (M2) on the dominant side - leads to motor aphasia (Broca's) and 
facio-brachial weakness • Inferior division of MCA (M2) on the dominant side - leads to sensory aphasia (Wernicke's) and 
contralateral superior quadrantanopia The following image of coronal section of cerebral hemisphere shows the segments of MCA: 1103 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient is found to have Wernicke’s aphasia without motor involvement. Where is the 
infarct likely to be?

options.a: ACA territory of the right hemisphere
options.b: ACA territory of the left hemisphere
options.c: MCA territory of the right hemisphere
options.d: MCA territory of the left hemisphere

questions.explanation:
The presence of Wernicke’s aphasia without motor involvement suggests an infarct in the MCA 
territory of the left (dominant) hemisphere. Wernicke’s area is located in the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant hemisphere (mostly the 
left side). This area is supplied by the inferior division of MCA. MCA divides into superior and inferior divisions in the Sylvian fissure. These branches are 
referred to as the M2 segments of MCA. • The superior division - supplies the frontal and the superior parietal cortex. • The inferior division - supplies the inferior parietal and temporal cortex. An infarct in the territory of the inferior division of MCA in the dominant hemisphere causes 
Wernicke’s aphasia without weakness. As the frontal cortex (containing the motor area) is 
supplied by the superior division and is not affected, weakness is not observed. An infarct in the inferior division of MCA of the non-dominant hemisphere (mostly the right side) 
causes hemineglect without weakness.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is not a feature of an anterior choroidal artery lesion?
questions.explanation:
Aphasia (dominant hemisphere), constructional apraxia and neglect (non-dominant hemisphere) 
are seen in MCA stem occlusion. These features are absent in anterior choroidal artery occlusion. Features common to both MCA and anterior choroidal artery occlusion include: • Contralateral hemiplegia • Hemianaesthesia • Homonymous hemianopia.

questions.question:
Question 18: A man is rushed to the ER after losing control of his car and crashing into a tree. 
Examination findings are given below. What is the most likely cause for his presentation?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of pontine haemorrhage. Clinical features of pontine 
haemorrhage are: • Deep coma • Quadriparesis and multiple cranial nerve dysfunction • Decerebrate rigidity • Pin-point pupils • Hyperpnea, hyperpyrexia, severe hypertension, and hyperhidrosis 1104 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: The presence of hyperpyrexia and pin-point pupils rule out the possibility of spinal cord 
trauma. Option B: Morphine poisoning is a differential diagnosis for pin-point pupils. But it leads to 
slower respiratory rate, not tachypnea. Option D: In ponto-medullary laceration, medullary involvement would cause respiratory 
depression, leading to apnea. But here tachypnea is noted.

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and left-sided limb weakness for the past 1 
hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg and her CT appears normal. What would be the 
next step of management?
questions.explanation:
Sudden onset hemiparesis with apparently normal CT indicates ischemic stroke in this patient. 
Intravenous thrombolysis(alteplase 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients 
with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period i.e., within 3-4.5 hours of symptom onset. Aspirin + clopidogrel(Option B) is used in secondary prevention of stroke and also to prevent 
stroke following TIA. Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) refer to episodes of stroke symptoms that have a brief duration, 
the standard definition of duration is <24 h, but most TIAs last <1 hr. TIAs may arise from 
emboli to the brain or from in situ thrombosis of an intracranial vessel. With a TIA, the occluded 
blood vessel reopens and neurologic function is restored. If a relevant brain infarction is identified 
on brain imaging, the clinical entity is now classified as stroke regardless of the duration of 
symptoms. The risk of stroke following a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is approximately 10-15% in the first 
three months, majorly in the first two days. A reliable estimation of this risk can be obtained using 
the ABCD2 score. Other options: Option A: If CT is normal it only rules out hemorrhagic stroke and changes of ischemic stroke 
usually take time to appear on NCCT. Option D: BP control is done when BP exceeds 220/120 mmHg, if there is malignant hypertension 
or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg and thrombolytic 
therapy is anticipated.

questions.question: Question 20: Thrombolysis is contraindicated in which of the following patients with ischaemic stroke?
questions.explanation:
A sustained blood pressure > 185/110 mmHg and recent myocardial infarction are 
contraindications for initiating thrombolysis in ischemic stroke.

questions.question:
Question 21: A patient with acute ischemic stroke requires IV thrombolysis. His symptoms had begun at 
6:30 PM and he was brought to the hospital by 7:00 PM. For this treatment to be beneficial 
for the patient, it should be administered within what time?
questions.explanation:
IV thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke has been proven to be beneficial up to 4.5 hours after the 
onset of symptoms according to European Cooperative Acute Stroke Study (ECASS) III. 1105 
Sold by @itachibot According to MoHFW (India), thrombolysis is to be carried out within 4.5 hours of symptom 
onset. IV tPA should be administered to all eligible acute stroke patients within 3 hours of last known 
normal and to a more selective group of eligible acute stroke patients (based on ECASS III 
exclusion criteria) within 4.5 hours of last known normal.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following features of stroke need not be treated?
questions.explanation:
Neglect is a feature of stroke that need not be treated. Although neglect indicates a poor 
prognosis, most patients recover without any treatment in 1-6 months. Dysphagia(Option A) poses a high risk of aspiration and hence can't be left untreated. 
Spasticity(Option B) can be treated with baclofen, tizanidine. Untreated, it creates a psychosocial 
impact on the patient. Fever(Option C) is deleterious in stroke patients and must be treated. Neglect can arise from injury to cortical-limbic-reticular network, that directs attention and 
integrates the localization and identification of a stimulus. Neglect is associated with poor scores 
and slower recovery, but severe neglect is rare beyond 6 months. Recovery is rapid in the first 2 
weeks, regardless of the side of stroke. By 3 months, patients might have some residual visual 
neglect. The choice of an intervention depends on the mechanism of neglect, the patient can be 
treated for an underaroused right hemisphere which has difficulty processing sensory inputs. Neurogenic dysphagia is an important cause of pulmonary infection in any patient with stroke, 
motor neuron disease, even transient dysphagia can lead to malnutrition, dehydration, aspiration 
pneumonia, and airway obstruction with asphyxia, it increases the risk of death and 
institutionalization. Early placement of nasogastric tube to feed patients after stroke has 
improved nutrition and reduced deaths. Spasticity is seen in less than 20% of stroke patients. Patients with bilateral weakness from 
hypoxic injury are likely to have signs of spasticity. Exaggerated cutaneous and autonomic reflexes 
and involuntary spasms are disabling problems associated with spasticity. Physical modalities like 
slow stretching movements and daily passive exercises will reduce symptoms of spasticity and risk 
of contractures. Baclofen, tizanidine, and clonidine are used in reducing clonus and extensor 
spasms.

questions.question:
Question 23: A woman on oral contraceptive pills presents with a headache for 2 days and paraparesis. 
What could be the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
The presence of headache and paraparesis in this patient with a history of oral contraceptive use 
is suggestive of cerebral venous thrombosis. Cerebral venous thrombosis is commonly seen in hypercoagulable states such as: • Oral contraceptive pill use • Pregnancy and puerperium • Inflammatory bowel disease • Dehydration 1106 
Sold by @itachibot • Intracranial infections. It presents with: • Headache (most common) • Seizures • Intracranial Hypertension • Focal neurological Deficits • Altered Mental status MR venography is used for diagnosis. The below image shows the empty delta sign seen on CECT or MRI with contrast in patients with 
sagittal sinus thrombosis.

questions.question: Question 24: What is the treatment of choice for a patient diagnosed with sagittal sinus thrombosis?
questions.explanation:
IV heparin is the drug of choice in cerebral venous thrombosis. It prevents further thrombosis and 
reduces venous hypertension and ischemia. Anticoagulation is often continued indefinitely if thrombophilia is diagnosed. If there is no underlying hypercoagulable state, treatment with vitamin K antagonists (VKAs) for 
3–6 months may be initiated and then converted to aspirin, depending on the degree of resolution 
of the venous sinus thrombus. Treatment of CVT: • Acute treatment - IV Heparin or LMWH • Maintenance therapy: • Warfarin for at least 3 months 1107 
Sold by @itachibot • In pregnant women with a history of CVT - anticoagulation with LMWH throughout pregnancy 
and till 8 weeks postpartum.

questions.question:
Question 25: A 40-year-old patient presents with headache and weakness of the right side of the body. He 
has difficulty in speaking also. Angiography shows a puff of smoke appearance. Which of the 
following statements regarding this disease is false?

options.a: It is an occlusive disease involving large intracranial arteries
options.c: Dawson’s fingers are the characteristic imaging finding

questions.explanation:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Moyamoya disease and Dawson's fingers is not a 
finding in this condition. Dawson fingers are a radiographic feature typically seen in multiple sclerosis (MS) The picture below demonstrates Dawson fingers. Moyamoya disease is an occlusive disease involving large intracranial arteries. It has a bimodal 
age distribution and is seen in the first and fourth decades: • Childhood moyamoya is characterized by ischemic manifestations • Adult moyamoya is characterized by hemorrhagic manifestations The first symptom is a stroke or recurrent TIA. Treatment is by surgical bypass of extracranial carotid arteries to the dura or middle cerebral 
artery. This may prevent stroke and haemorrhage. The below image shows the MR angiography findings in a patient with Moyamoya disease. 1108 
Sold by @itachibot Note: As this is a chronic condition, the lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral 
circulation around the occlusive lesion. This is seen as a 'puff of smoke' (moyamoya in Japanese) 
on X-ray angiography.

questions.question: Question 26: Which among the following is not a component of CHA2DS2-VASc score?
questions.explanation:
Age > 60 years is not a component of the CHADS2-VASc score. Age > 75years and age group 
65-75 yrs are the two age criteria considered in the score. The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients who have atrial 
fibrillation. Anticoagulation therapy is given when the score is 2. Patients with a score of 1 may 
also be considered for anticoagulation therapy. Anticoagulation therapy is given for all the patients of AF having mitral stenosis, hypertrophic 
cardiomyopathy, or a history of stroke. 1109 
Sold by @itachibot Brainstem Syndromes and Hemorrhagic Stroke
